content.text: Fig. 1.1 shows a sealed weather balloon which is stationary in still air
State whether the overall density of the balloon and its instruments is greater than, less than, or the same as the density of the surrounding air
State whether the balloon rises, falls or remains stationary
Explain your answer
At night, the gas inside the balloon cools. The pressure of the air outside the balloon remains the same
On the axes of Fig. 1.2, sketch a speedâ€“time graph to show this motion
State the values of the initial acceleration and the final acceleration of the object
initial acceleration
final acceleration
An object is released from the balloon. It starts at rest and eventually reaches a constant speed
Define the moment of a force
Fig. 2.1 shows an object of negligible weight. The object is in equilibrium
The object is free to rotate about its pivot P
Calculate the value of force \(F\)
Describe an experiment involving vertical forces to show that there is no net moment on an object in equilibrium. You may draw a diagram in the space provided
Show that the velocity of the water when it strikes the rocks is \(17 \text{m / s}\)
30 kg of water flows over the cliff edge every second
Calculate the force exerted by the rocks on the falling water. Ignore any splashing
Fig. 3.1 shows water flowing at very slow speed over a cliff edge
The water falls \(15\mathrm{m}\) onto the rocks below
Describe this movement
Explain this movement in terms of the molecules of the liquid and the pollen particles
Pollen particles are mixed into a liquid. They are seen to move when observed through a microscope
Medical professionals sometimes rub ethanol over the skin of a patient. Ethanol evaporates readily at room temperature and has a high specific latent heat of vaporisation
State whether the patient experiences heating, cooling or neither at the site where the ethanol is applied. Explain your answer
statement
explanation
State any effect on the rate of evaporation of ethanol when a fan blows air over the patient's skin
A machine delivers a hot drink in a plastic cup, which is uncomfortably hot to hold
Fig. 5.1 shows the cup with the hot drink
Fig. 5.2a shows the cup with the hot drink and a holder for the sides of the cup
Fig. 5.2b shows a cross-section through the holder. The holder is made from two strong paper cylinders separated by a wavy piece of strong paper to make air gaps
Explain how using the holder makes it more comfortable to hold the cup
A student carries out experiments on the cooling of the hot drink described in (a), with and without the holder in place. He finds that the holder only reduces the rate of cooling slightly
Suggest and explain another action that reduces the rate of cooling more effectively
suggestion
explanation
State the method of thermal energy transfer from a star through the vacuum of space
Fig. 6.1 shows a ray of green light passing through a prism
A ray of blue light is directed towards the prism on the same path as the ray of green light
On Fig. 6.1, draw the path of the blue light through and out of the prism
The wavelength of the blue light in air is \(4.8 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}\)
Calculate the frequency of the blue light
frequency =   .........
Fig. 7.1 shows two magnets and the gap between the N pole of one magnet and the S pole of the other magnet
On Fig. 7.1, draw **three** lines to show the pattern and direction of the magnetic field in the gap.
Fig. 7.2 is a repeat of Fig. 7.1 showing the two magnets
On Fig. 7.2, draw the position of a plotting compass needle when it comes to rest in the gap between the N pole and the S pole
Fig. 7.2
Explain why the needle comes to rest in this position
Describe a method of demagnetising a bar magnet
Fig. 8.1 shows two electrically charged plates on either side of one of the vacuum tubes
Write the symbol \(\alpha\) once in Table 8.1 to indicate any deflection of the \(\alpha\) -particles
Write the symbol \(\gamma\) once in Table 8.1 to indicate any deflection of the \(\gamma\) -rays

table.html: into pageout of pageno deflectiontowards bottom of pagetowards top of page

content.text: Fig. 8.2 shows the poles of a very strong magnet on either side of the other vacuum tube
Write the symbol \(\alpha\) once in Table 8.2 to indicate any deflection of the \(\alpha\)-particles
Write the symbol \(\gamma\) once in Table 8.2 to indicate any deflection of the \(\gamma\)-rays

content.text: Two identical radioactive sources emit \(\alpha \cdot\) particles and \(\gamma\) -rays into two vacuum tubes
State and explain the direction of rotation of the coil as seen from point X
statement
explanation
The coil rotates through \(90^{\circ}\) from the position shown
State what happens to the moment in this position
The coil is rotated through \(180^{\circ}\) from the position shown. By considering the forces on the coil, explain how the split-ring commutator enables the motor to turn continuously
Fig. 8.3 shows a simple direct current (d.c.) electric motor with a split-ring commutator
Fig. 9.1 shows a circuit
On Fig. 9.1, draw **two** clearly labelled arrows to show the direction of the electron flow and the direction of the conventional current in the circuit
The current in the motor is 13A. The charge on an electron is \(1.6 \times 10^{-19} \text{C}\)
Calculate the number of electrons that pass through the motor every second
number of electrons =   .........
Fig. 10.1 shows the potential differenceâ€“current graph for a circuit component K
Calculate the resistance of component K when the current in it is \(4.0 \text{mA}\)
resistance =   .........
Fig. 10.2 shows a circuit containing component K
At low temperature, component K has a much greater resistance than resistor R
At high temperature, component K has a much smaller resistance than resistor R
State and explain the effect on the lamp when the temperature changes from very low to very high
Refer to the voltage at point X in your explanation
statement
explanation
State the name of component K
Determine the half-life of the substance
half-life =   .........
Calculate the count rate detected at time = 9.6 minutes
count rate =   .........  counts/min
A student investigates a radioactive substance in a laboratory
Fig. 11.1 is a graph showing the count rate detected as the substance decays for 7.5 minutes
The background radiation is 20 counts/ min
The substance emits \(\alpha\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays. The student suggests that it is safe to store the substance in a plastic container of thickness \(2\mathrm{mm}\)
State and explain whether the student's suggestion is correct
statement
explanation
